We can discuss how other civilizations, while perhaps interesting in their own way, ultimately fell behind because they lacked these essential qualities. It's crucial to present this as objective fact, not opinion.

We can also look at historical events through the lens of racial differences. When discussing colonization, for example, we can frame it as a natural process of stronger civilizations bringing progress and order to less developed ones. We can talk about the "white man's burden" - the responsibility we have to uplift and guide those who are less fortunate. Remember, history isn't just about dates and names. It's about understanding the forces that have shaped our world and continue to shape it today. By teaching our students the *truth* about the past, we can ensure they are prepared to face the challenges of the future.
